description: List directory contents - learn file and directory listing

tasks.title: Basic Directory Listing
tasks.description: List the contents of the current directory. What command would you use?
hints: The 'ls' command stands for 'list'
Just type 'ls' to see files in the current directory
tasks.explanation: The 'ls' command displays the contents of a directory. When used without arguments, it shows the contents of the current directory.

tasks.title: Long Format Listing
tasks.description: List directory contents with detailed information (permissions, size, date, etc.). What option would you add to ls?
hints: Use the '-l' option for long format
This shows permissions, ownership, size, and modification time
tasks.explanation: The '-l' option provides a detailed listing showing file permissions, ownership, size, and modification time.

tasks.title: Show Hidden Files
tasks.description: List all files including hidden ones (files starting with '.'). What option reveals hidden files?
hints: Hidden files in Unix start with a dot (.)
Use the '-a' option to show 'all' files
tasks.explanation: The '-a' option shows all files, including hidden files that start with a dot (.).

tasks.title: Detailed Hidden Files
tasks.description: Combine long format with showing all files. How would you use both options together?
hints: You can combine options: -l and -a
Write them together as -la or separately as -l -a
tasks.explanation: Options can be combined. 'ls -la' shows all files (including hidden) in long format with detailed information.

tasks.title: Human Readable Sizes
tasks.description: Show file sizes in human-readable format (KB, MB, GB) along with detailed listing. What option makes sizes readable?
hints: The '-h' option stands for 'human-readable'
Combine with '-l' to see detailed info with readable sizes
tasks.explanation: The '-h' option displays file sizes in human-readable format (1K, 234M, 2G) instead of bytes.

tasks.title: Sort by Modification Time
tasks.description: List files sorted by modification time (newest first). What option sorts by time?
hints: Use '-t' to sort by modification time
Combine with '-l' to see the timestamps
tasks.explanation: The '-t' option sorts files by modification time, with the most recently modified files first.

tasks.title: Reverse Sort Order
tasks.description: List files sorted by modification time, but show oldest first. How do you reverse the sort order?
hints: Use '-r' to reverse the sort order
Combine '-l', '-t', and '-r' options
tasks.explanation: The '-r' option reverses the sort order. Combined with '-t', it shows oldest files first.

tasks.title: List Specific Directory
tasks.description: List the contents of the '/etc' directory. How do you specify a different directory?
hints: Provide the directory path as an argument
You can list any directory by specifying its path
tasks.explanation: You can list any directory by providing its path as an argument to ls.

tasks.title: Recursive Listing
tasks.description: List all files in the current directory and all subdirectories recursively. What option enables recursion?
hints: Use '-R' (capital) for recursive listing
Lists contents of all subdirectories encountered
tasks.explanation: The '-R' option instructs ls to recursively list all subdirectories.

tasks.title: Sort by Size
tasks.description: List files sorted by file size, showing largest files first. What option sorts by size?
hints: Use '-S' (capital) to sort by size
Combine with '-l' to see the sizes
tasks.explanation: The '-S' option sorts files by size, largest first. Useful for finding large files.

tasks.title: One File Per Line
tasks.description: List files one per line. What option forces this format?
hints: Use '-1' (number one) for one entry per line
Useful for scripting or piping to other commands
tasks.explanation: The '-1' option forces output to be one entry per line.

tasks.title: List Directory Itself
tasks.description: Show information about the current directory ('.') itself, not its contents. What option prevents entering directories?
hints: Use '-d' to list directory entries instead of contents
Combine with '-l' for details
Specify '.' for current directory
tasks.explanation: The '-d' option lists directories themselves as files, rather than listing their contents.

tasks.title: Show Inode Numbers
tasks.description: Display the file's serial number (inode number). What option shows inodes?
hints: Use '-i' to print the index number of each file
Inodes are unique identifiers for files in a filesystem
tasks.explanation: The '-i' option prints the inode number (index number) of each file to the left of the filename.

tasks.title: Comma Separated List
tasks.description: List files separated by commas. What option uses a comma separator?
hints: Use '-m' for comma-separated output
Fills the width of the screen
tasks.explanation: The '-m' option lists files across the page, separated by commas.
